title: The NBA has a defensive three seconds problem
description: We looked at the data and found that defensive three seconds doesn’t matter when the game matters.

section.title: The NBA has a defensive three seconds problem
section.text:
A micro-investigation
by Owen Phillips + Russell Goldenberg
section.narration: We looked at the data and found that defensive three seconds doesn’t matter when the game matters.

section.text: Quick refresher on defensive three seconds — basically, the floor is lava.
section.narration: In the NBA, defenders aren’t allowed to spend more than three seconds in the lane unless they’re guarding someone. Basically it is like a mini-game of the floor is lava. It’s a very clear rule, but unlike other fouls, defensive three seconds isn’t called consistently.

section.text: The average defensive three seconds violation comes midway through the second quarter.
As the game progresses, defensive three seconds is called less often.
Want more proof? It was called just once out of 141 occurrences in close games.
